yes. I made mistake, not transitivity but symmetry:

The equals method implements an equivalence relation:

  a.. It is reflexive: for any reference value x, x.equals(x) should return
true.
  b.. It is symmetric: for any reference values x and y, x.equals(y) should
return true if and only if y.equals(x) returns true.
  c.. It is transitive: for any reference values x, y, and z, if x.equals(y)
returns true and y.equals(z) returns true, then x.equals(z) should return
true.
  d.. It is consistent: for any reference values x and y, multiple
invocations of x.equals(y) consistently return true or consistently return
false, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is
modified.
  e.. For any non-null reference value x, x.equals(null) should return
false.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Lothar Kimmeringer" <junit@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 10:32 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)


> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
>
> On Fri, 10 May 2002 21:13:21 +0300, Alexander Zynevich wrote:
>
> >it seems to me that these methods does not test transitivity
> >of equals, which is declared in Java Specification. I think
> >documentation should state that assertEquals(p1,p2) is
> >completely equiv to assertTrue(p1.equals(p2))
>
> I'm not sure, but is it possible that you mistake transitivity
> for reflexivity?
>
> If a.equals(b) and b.equals(c) then it's also true to say
> a.equals(c). With a method with only two parameters it's not
> possible to prove transitivity, so I don't think that this
> must be mentioned in the documentation.
>
>
> Regards, Lothar
>
